props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese praises Daniel Andrews as "a man of great conviction", after the Victorian premier's sudden resignation announcement.Â Follow all the updates in our live blog.

title.children: Albanese pays tribute to Andrews as Victorian premier announces shock resignation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Tomorrow at midday the Labor caucus will meet to appoint a successor to Daniel Andrews. He's said he won't be meddling in party politics and will leave it to his colleagues to choose a new leader. Deputy Premier Jacinta Allan, a political mentee of Mr Andrews and also part of Labor's Socialist Left faction, is largely seen as his heir apparent. Public Transport Minister Ben Carroll, from Labor's Right faction, is also in the mix, with speculation he'll run for the position of deputy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Who might replace Daniel Andrews?

children.content: Tomorrow at midday the Labor caucus will meet to appoint a successor to Daniel Andrews.
He's said he won't be meddling in party politics and will leave it to his colleagues to choose a new leader.
Deputy Premier Jacinta Allan
, a political mentee of Mr Andrews and also part of Labor's Socialist Left faction, is largely seen as his heir apparent.

props.alt: Jacinta Allan at a press conference.

children.content: Jacinta Allan is the Labor MP for Bendigo East and likely successor.
(AAP: Diego Fedele)
Public Transport Minister Ben Carroll
, from Labor's Right faction, is also in the mix, with speculation he'll run for the position of deputy.
Ben Carroll is tipped to run as deputy leader of the party.
(AAP: Joel Carrett)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Daniel Andrews will resign as Victorian premier, effective 5pm tomorrow His successor will be chosen at a Labor caucus meeting at midday tomorrow He has indicated he's likely to pursue a private sector role He says he won't be lobbying colleagues to elect a particular successor
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Missed the presser? These are the main points

children.content: Daniel Andrews will resign as Victorian premier, effective
5pm tomorrow
His successor will be chosen at a Labor caucus meeting at
midday tomorrow
He has indicated he's likely to pursue a private sector role
He says he won't be lobbying colleagues to elect a particular successor

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Daniel Andrews says the Labor caucus will meet at midday tomorrow and he won't speculate on who may be elected as his successor. "That'll be determined by the colleagues and I am deeply respectful of that process," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Andrews's successor to be chosen at midday tomorrow

children.content: Daniel Andrews says the Labor caucus will meet at midday tomorrow and he won't speculate on who may be elected as his successor.
"That'll be determined by the colleagues and I am deeply respectful of that process," he says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Popular tourist destination Byron Bay will limit the availability of some properties for short-term holiday rentals, as authorities try to free up homes for residents amid a nationwide housing crisis. The New South Wales state government has approved a request from the Byron Shire council to limit the short-term rents for some properties to 60 days per year to help boost the number of houses available for long-term stays. The decision comes days after Melbourne introduced the country's first tax on Airbnb-like stays, which the authorities in Victoria said would go towards funding more social housing. Byron Bay is a beachside destination popular with tourists and celebrities, including actor Chris Hemsworth (who owns a home there). For more, here's our coverage of the issue:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Byron Bay landords forced to cap short-term rentals at 60 days amid housing crisis

featuredLink.title: Byron Bay's holiday home market set to shrink to help locals struggling to find a home

children.content: Popular tourist destination Byron Bay will limit the availability of some properties for short-term holiday rentals, as authorities try to free up homes for residents amid a nationwide housing crisis.

The New South Wales state government has approved a request from the Byron Shire council to limit the short-term rents for some properties to 60 days per year to help boost the number of houses available for long-term stays.
The decision comes days after Melbourne introduced the country's first tax on Airbnb-like stays, which the authorities in Victoria said would go towards funding more social housing.
Byron Bay is a beachside destination popular with tourists and celebrities, including actor Chris Hemsworth (who owns a home there).
For more, here's our coverage of the issue:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ has been ordered by the Federal Court to to pay a $15 million penalty for misleading customers about funds available in certain credit card accounts. The Australian lender falsely indicated to customers that they could rely on a 'cash advance' from funds stated to be their 'Available Funds' without incurring fees and interest. The error resulted in customers being charged with thousands of dollars in fees while the average remediation paid was around $45 per affected account, according to the Australian Securities & Investments Commission (ASIC) â the regulator which sued ANZ. "Many ANZ customers relied on the account information displayed by the bank and were charged fees that were inconsistent with that information," said ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court. So far, the country's fourth-largest bank has provided remediation payments of more than $8.3 million to about 186,000 accounts that were charged with fees and interest between May 2016 and November 2018. "The court found ANZ breached the ASIC Act and the National Consumer Credit Protection Act," the regulator said. In a separate statement, the lender acknowledged the breach and agreed to further remediation for the period from November 2018 to September 2021. "ANZ accepts responsibility for what has occurred and apologises to its customers, and has addressed the issues that gave rise to the contraventions," the lender said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ANZ fined $15m for misleading customers over funds

children.content: ANZ has been ordered by the Federal Court to to pay a
$15 million
penalty for misleading customers about funds available in certain credit card accounts.
The Australian lender falsely indicated to customers that they could rely on a 'cash advance' from funds stated to be their 'Available Funds' without incurring fees and interest.
The error resulted in customers being charged with thousands of dollars in fees while the average remediation paid was around $45 per affected account, according to the Australian Securities
Investments Commission (ASIC) â the regulator which sued ANZ.
"Many ANZ customers relied on the account information displayed by the bank and were charged fees that were inconsistent with that information," said ASIC deputy chair Sarah Court.

So far, the country's fourth-largest bank has provided remediation payments of more than $8.3 million to about 186,000 accounts that were charged with fees and interest between May 2016 and November 2018.
"The court found ANZ breached the ASIC Act and the National Consumer Credit Protection Act," the regulator said.
In a separate statement, the lender acknowledged the breach and agreed to further remediation for the period from November 2018 to September 2021.
"ANZ accepts responsibility for what has occurred and apologises to its customers, and has addressed the issues that gave rise to the contraventions," the lender said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Qantas shares are losing value as pressure mounts on the chairman Richard Goyder to step down. The airline has also warned higher fuel costs may push ticket prices up. Analyst firm Jefferies has lowered its earning per share (EPS) forecast for Qantas by 14 per cent, but says "positive" customer improvement initiatives along with ongoing strength in demand suggest damage to the brand is fixable. By 12:15pm AEST, Qantas' share price was down 1.5% t o $5.15. It looks even worse when you step back and look at Qantas shares. They have dropped 5.3% in the past week, and have plunged 17.3% in the past month.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas shares in nosedive
